predictionSection.p1: The forecast chart displays a linear regression that allows the user to select the country, the type of energy data, and the number of years to project consumption from 2022 onwards.
predictionSection.p2: Linear regression is a statistical technique used to predict the future behavior of a variable based on historical data. In the case of the presented work, the model identifies a relationship between time (x-axis) and the type of data (y-axis) to provide estimates of how consumption may evolve in the coming years.

renewables.title: Top 10 countries with the highest renewable energy production
renewables.p1: Renewable energy is an energy source that is obtained from natural resources that are naturally replenished, such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat.
renewables.p2: Renewable energy is an alternative to non-renewable energy, which is obtained from finite resources, such as coal, oil, and natural gas.

nonRenewables.p1: Non-renewable energy is an energy source that is obtained from finite resources, such as coal, oil, and natural gas.
nonRenewables.p2: Non-renewable energy is an alternative to renewable energy, which is obtained from natural resources that are naturally replenished, such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat.

about.p1: This work was developed by students from the Catholic University of Santos in the Computer Science program. The focus is on the analysis of energy data and the use of prediction and visualization tools to understand the behavior of global energy consumption.

tech.title: Technologies Used
tech.p: The project was developed using the following technologies:
tech.react: JavaScript framework for developing the site interface.
tech.python: Language used for data processing and prediction.
tech.flask: Used to create the API that processes the data.
tech.iframe: Used to embed PowerBI dashboards into the website.

graph1.title: Graph 1: Line
graph1.description: Shows the evolution of the energy metric over the years for the selected country, with X-axis (years) and Y-axis (metric value).

graph2.title: Graph 2: Bars
graph2.description: Displays the countries in descending order, comparing them by the selected metric.

graph3.title: Graph 3: Map Bubbles
graph3.description: Shows the global distribution of the selected metric, with the size of the bubbles indicating the magnitude for each country.

graph4.title: Graph 4: Doughnut
graph4.description: Displays the proportion of renewable versus non-renewable energy for the selected country.

footer.copy: Website developed by students from Unisantos
